title: Integration – Sentence Patterns C & D (Linking and Giving)
goals: Identify and translate Sentence Pattern C (Linking) and D (Indirect Object)
Recognize forms of est as linking verbs
Understand dative endings (-ae, -ō) showing the receiver of the action
Review all four sentence patterns A–D

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 13 Day 3. Today we learn the last two sentence patterns: linking and giving.
First, Pattern C: the linking verb. It joins a subject and an adjective. Example: Deus est bonus – God is good.
Say it together: Deus est bonus. Which word is the linking verb?
Right—est means ‘is’. It links the subject and what is true about it.
Now Pattern D: giving. Example: Dominus servō donum dat – The lord gives a gift to the servant.
The word servō ends in –ō. That shows the dative case—the receiver of the action.
Try: Puella puerō aquam dat – The girl gives water to the boy.
Excellent! Let’s chant all four patterns: A – Puella amat, B – Puella rosam amat, C – Deus est bonus, D – Dominus servō donum dat.
Mini quiz: Which patterns have direct objects? Which has a linking verb? Which has an indirect object?
Correct! B and D have direct objects, D adds an indirect one, and C has the linking verb est.
Faith phrase: Verbum Dei verum est – The Word of God is true. Each sentence we form should tell something true.
Virtue reflection – Truth joins words rightly, just as est joins ideas rightly. God’s truth links all things.
Optime! Tomorrow we’ll review and celebrate mastery of all patterns A through D.
